articles.headline: Prosecutors Ask Witnesses Whether Trump Acknowledged He Lost 2020 Race
articles.snippet: Jared Kushner was questioned before a federal grand jury as prosecutors appeared to be trying to establish if the former president knew his efforts to stay in power were built on a lie.
articles.abstract: Jared Kushner was questioned before a federal grand jury as prosecutors appeared to be trying to establish if the former president knew his efforts to stay in power were built on a lie.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors investigating former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election have questioned multiple witnesses in recent weeks — including Mr. Trump’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner — about whether Mr. Trump had privately acknowledged in the days after the 2020 election that he had lost, according to four people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Once ‘The Nanny,’ Now Center Stage as the Actors’ Union Leader
articles.snippet: Fran Drescher, who became a household name for her role on a 1990s sitcom, is now president of the union going on strike.
articles.abstract: Fran Drescher, who became a household name for her role on a 1990s sitcom, is now president of the union going on strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stage was different, and so was the tone. But the voice was unmistakable.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: ‘As Long as It Takes’: Biden Adds to Talk of a New Cold War
articles.snippet: But that oversimplifies a complex global situation, others say, with a weakened Russia and with China facing serious problems of its own.
articles.abstract: But that oversimplifies a complex global situation, others say, with a weakened Russia and with China facing serious problems of its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden and his national security team have contended since he took office that all the easy, tempting comparisons between this era and the Cold War are misleading, a vast oversimplification of a complex geopolitical moment.

articles.headline: What Happens When You Ask a Chinese Chatbot About Taiwan?
articles.snippet: We spoke in Chinese to Baidu’s Ernie and the American standard-bearer, ChatGPT. This is what we found.
articles.abstract: We spoke in Chinese to Baidu’s Ernie and the American standard-bearer, ChatGPT. This is what we found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, China’s Baidu unveiled a chatbot that it claimed was better than ChatGPT, the one developed by Silicon Valley’s OpenAI. ChatGPT was released last fall and set off a fund-raising and engineering frenzy in a flourishing field called generative artificial intelligence, a term for technology that can create text or images when prompted by a user.
articles.byline: By Chang Che and Olivia Wang

articles.headline: With Offices Vacant, London’s Canary Wharf Seeks Growth Beyond Banking
articles.snippet: A major bank is leaving its headquarters in London’s purpose-built financial district. But the district’s owner has other plans for the area, which may help it survive the pressures it faces.
articles.abstract: A major bank is leaving its headquarters in London’s purpose-built financial district. But the district’s owner has other plans for the area, which may help it survive the pressures it faces.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gleaming skyscrapers of London’s east skyline, built almost 40 years ago, are home to the headquarters of the world’s biggest banks and tens of thousands of their office workers.

articles.headline: House Narrowly Passes Defense Bill, Setting Up Showdown Over Social Issues
articles.snippet: Republicans loaded the measure with a raft of social policy provisions — including limits on abortions, gender transition procedures and diversity training — that have little chance of surviving in the Senate.
articles.abstract: Republicans loaded the measure with a raft of social policy provisions — including limits on abortions, gender transition procedures and diversity training — that have little chance of surviving in the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans on Friday rammed through the House a deeply partisan defense bill that would limit abortion access, transgender care and diversity training for military personnel, setting up a showdown with the Senate. The coming fight could imperil the crucial annual measure to provide a pay raise for troops, set defense policy to counter U.S. adversaries and sustain Pentagon programs at a time of rising threats.

articles.headline: Insurer’s Retreat in Florida Signals Crisis With No Easy Fix
articles.snippet: Farmers is ending some policies in the Sunshine State as insurers struggle with the rising costs of covering climate change-related damage. No one can agree on whom to blame.
articles.abstract: Farmers is ending some policies in the Sunshine State as insurers struggle with the rising costs of covering climate change-related damage. No one can agree on whom to blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: Insurers are trapped in a riddle: In a world where the risk of costly disasters is rising but high premiums are squeezing policyholders and angering state regulators, how can they continue to make money?

articles.headline: Uruguay Saw Opportunity in China. It Got Schooled in the Hazards of Trade.
articles.snippet: Uruguay’s pursuit of a trade deal with China has angered its powerful neighbors while failing to yield economic gains.
articles.abstract: Uruguay’s pursuit of a trade deal with China has angered its powerful neighbors while failing to yield economic gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Word that Uruguay was seeking a trade deal with China prompted exultation at El Álamo ranch, a lush expanse of grass punctuated by cactus and herds of cattle on the eastern plains of Uruguay.

articles.headline: Ruined, Empty, Mined and Overgrown: Ukraine’s Forgotten Villages
articles.snippet: Settlements along Ukraine’s eastern steppe were reduced to wreckage as the war passed through them. Now choked with weeds and with few residents, they are at risk of disappearing.
articles.abstract: Settlements along Ukraine’s eastern steppe were reduced to wreckage as the war passed through them. Now choked with weeds and with few residents, they are at risk of disappearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leave the eastern Ukrainian city of Izium and turn west onto rougher roads, where dead trees and twisted power lines give way to a string of shattered villages.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Mauricio Lima

articles.headline: Investors Look for Reasons the Market Could ‘Grind Higher’
articles.snippet: Companies are expected to report a fall in profits, but some analysts see brighter times ahead.
articles.abstract: Companies are expected to report a fall in profits, but some analysts see brighter times ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: As companies prepare to open their books to investors over the coming weeks, in the quarterly ritual known as earnings season, market watchers are balancing relatively weak estimates for past profits with brighter forecasts for future performance.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and J. Edward Moreno

articles.headline: New Heat Wave Descends on Europe, as It Struggles to Adapt
articles.snippet: European governments have been slow to put in place broader mitigation strategies for extreme heat, allowing deaths to increase. This year may be no different.
articles.abstract: European governments have been slow to put in place broader mitigation strategies for extreme heat, allowing deaths to increase. This year may be no different.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tourists sheltered under umbrellas as they lined up at Florence’s majestic cathedral this week, looking for shade. Street vendors peddled fans and straw hats. Locals splashed their faces at water fountains, all seeking a respite from Europe’s latest heat wave.

articles.headline: Autoworkers Open Contract Talks in a Fighting Mood
articles.snippet: The U.A.W., with a more confrontational leader, aims to win back wage and benefit concessions and insulate jobs from the rise of electric vehicles.
articles.abstract: The U.A.W., with a more confrontational leader, aims to win back wage and benefit concessions and insulate jobs from the rise of electric vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: The three Detroit automakers and the United Auto Workers union have begun negotiating a new labor contract in what could become the most contentious talks between the two sides in perhaps half a century.
